article.title: Production of reactive oxygen species and involvement of bioprotectants during anhydrobiosis in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis

funding.name: European Union’s Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme

article.abstract: Water unavailability is an abiotic stress causing unfavourable conditions for life. Nevertheless, some animals evolved anhydrobiosis, a strategy allowing for the reversible organism dehydration and suspension of metabolism as a direct response to habitat desiccation.

sections.introduction: Insufficient hydration is extremely stressful for living organisms as water is required for metabolic reactions.
sections.methods: The eutardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis Guidetti et al. 2019 was used as target species.
sections.results: The overall level of intracellular Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) was assessed using the fluorescent probe 2,7-dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate (DCFH2-DA).
sections.discussion: This study provides an evaluation of oxidative stress production during desiccation in tardigrades through the direct assessment of the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in storage cells.

article.insights_summary: This study provides an evaluation of oxidative stress production during desiccation in tardigrades through the direct assessment of the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in storage cells.
article.acknowledgments: This work has received funding from the European Union’s Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme under the Marie Skłodowska-Curie Grant agreement No. 734434 and FAR 2015 of the Department of Life Sciences, UNIMORE.
